Now creating comprehensive audit report with findings.", "toolContext": "After batch security analysis, consolidating findings into structured audit report document.", "primaryGoal": "Document security audit findings", "subgoal": "Create comprehensive security audit report"}, "filePath": "security/audits/auth_security_audit_2025-11-22.md", "content": "# Authentication Security Audit - 2025-11-22

## Summary
Completed comprehensive security analysis of 8 authentication modules using batch execution.

## Critical Issues (3)
1. login.py: Passwords logged in plaintext during debug mode
2. jwt.py: Weak signature algorithm (HS256 with short key)
3. session.py: Session tokens not properly invalidated on logout

## Recommendations (7)
1. Implement bcrypt for password hashing
2. Upgrade JWT to RS256 algorithm
3. Add rate limiting to login endpoints
4. Enable CSRF protection for session-based auth
5. Implement token rotation for OAuth flows
6. Add security headers to all auth responses
7. Enable audit logging for all auth events

## Modules Analyzed
- auth/login.py
- auth/register.py
- auth/oauth.py
- auth/jwt.py
- auth/session.py
- auth/password_reset.py
- auth/two_factor.py
- auth/middleware.py
", "createFolders": true}

Reorganize my project files into the new folder structure

To reorganize your project files safely, I'll use this multi-step approach:

**Step 1: Discovery** (vaultLibrarian_searchContent)
- Search and catalog all project files
- Identify internal links between files

**Step 2: Create Structure** (vaultManager_createFolder)
- Set up the new folder hierarchy first
- Ensure no naming conflicts

**Step 3: Move Files** (vaultManager_moveFile)
- Relocate files to new locations
- Process in batches to avoid errors

**Step 4: Update References** (contentManager_updateContent)
- Fix all internal links to reflect new paths
- Verify no broken references remain

This approach ensures we don't lose any files or break existing links. Should I proceed with Step 1 to catalog your files first?

Set up version tracking for my important docs

For version tracking within the vault, here are approaches:

**Option A: Manual Versioning**
- Create versions/ subfolder per doc
- Copy before major changes: doc_v1.md, doc_v2.md
- Pros: Simple, visible history
- Cons: Manual process, storage overhead

**Option B: Changelog Approach**
- Maintain ## Changelog section in each doc
- Date-stamped entries for changes
- Pros: History in same file
- Cons: Can clutter document

**Option C: Diff-Based Archives**
- Periodic snapshots to Archive/
- Named by date: doc_2024-01-15.md
- Pros: Clean main docs
- Cons: Requires compare tool for diffs

**Option D: External Git Integration**
- Use git for actual version control
- Best for comprehensive history
- Requires git knowledge

**My recommendation:** Option A for critical docs + Option B for moderate importance.

Set up a complete GTD task management system

A GTD system in Obsidian can be implemented several ways:

**Option A: Task Plugin Integration**
- Use Obsidian Tasks plugin queries
- Tasks scattered across project notes
- Central dashboard with task queries
- Pros: Tasks live with context
- Cons: Requires plugin familiarity

**Option B: Folder-Based GTD**
- Separate folders: Inbox, Next Actions, Waiting, Someday
- Move notes between folders as status changes
- Pros: Visual organization
- Cons: Notes can only be in one folder

**Option C: Tag + Dataview System**
- Use status tags (#next, #waiting, #someday)
- Dataview queries for dynamic lists
- Pros: Flexible, notes stay in context
- Cons: Requires Dataview knowledge

Each approach has different trade-offs for maintenance and visibility. Which fits your workflow preference?

Standardize the frontmatter across all my notes

Standardizing frontmatter across your vault requires a methodical approach:

**Phase 1: Audit** (vaultLibrarian_searchContent)
- Scan all notes for existing frontmatter fields
- Identify all unique property names and formats
- Find notes missing frontmatter entirely

**Phase 2: Schema Design**
- Define standard fields (created, modified, tags, type)
- Create naming conventions for custom fields
- Plan for existing data migration

**Phase 3: Migration** (vaultManager_updateFrontmatter)
- Add missing required fields with defaults
- Normalize inconsistent field names
- Convert incompatible data formats

**Phase 4: Validation**
- Verify all notes have required fields
- Check for any conversion errors
- Document the new schema for reference

This avoids data loss while achieving consistency. Should I start with the audit phase?

- Cons: Notes become cluttered

**Option B: Separate Flashcard Notes**

- Link back to source notes
- Pros: Clean separation
- Cons: Duplicates some content

**Option C: Anki Export**
- Format notes for Anki import
- Use Obsidian as content source only
- Pros: Powerful SRS algorithm
- Cons: Two systems to maintain

Find and fix all the broken links in my vault

Fixing broken links requires a systematic approach:

**Phase 1: Discovery** (vaultLibrarian_searchContent)
- Scan vault for all internal links
- Identify links pointing to non-existent notes
- Catalog renamed or moved files

**Phase 2: Analysis**
- Categorize broken links by type:
  - Renamed files (likely match exists)
  - Deleted content (no match)
  - Typos in link text
- Assess fix complexity for each

**Phase 3: Resolution** (contentManager_updateNote)
- Update links to renamed files
- Create placeholder notes for missing targets
- Fix typos in link syntax

**Phase 4: Prevention**
- Document file naming conventions
- Suggest using note aliases for flexibility

Create a system for tracking meeting action items

There are several effective approaches for meeting action item tracking:

**Option A: Embedded Tasks**
- Tasks inline in meeting notes with - [ ] syntax
- Query all tasks across meetings with Tasks plugin
- Pros: Action items stay with context
- Cons: Harder to see all actions at once

**Option B: Centralized Action Register**
- Dedicated note for all action items
- Link back to source meeting
- Pros: Single view of all actions
- Cons: Requires manual copying/linking

**Option C: Person-Based Tracking**
- Action items under each person's note
- Filter by assignee easily
- Pros: Great for team accountability
- Cons: More complex setup

**Option D: Project-Based**
- Actions flow to relevant project notes
- Meeting note links to project
- Pros: Actions live where work happens
- Cons: Meeting context separated

How do you typically need to view action items - by meeting, person, or project?

Help me track versions and changes to my important notes

Version tracking in Obsidian can be achieved through several methods:

**Option A: Git Integration**
- Use git for version control
- Full history with diff capability
- Pros: Industry standard, complete history
- Cons: Technical setup, storage overhead

**Option B: Manual Version Snapshots**
- Create dated copies for major changes
- Archive folder for old versions
- Pros: Simple, no plugins needed
- Cons: Manual effort, duplicate files

**Option C: Changelog Section**
- Add changelog section to important notes
- Document significant changes inline
- Pros: History with the note
- Cons: Only tracks intentional changes

**Option D: Obsidian Sync History**
- Use Obsidian Sync's version history
- Automatic snapshots on each sync
- Pros: Automatic, easy restore
- Cons: Paid feature, limited retention

What level of version tracking do you need - full history or just major milestones?

**Phase 1: Assessment** (vaultLibrarian_searchContent)

- Count total replacements needed

**Phase 2: Categorization**
- Group by file type (notes, templates, configs)
- Identify sensitive areas (filenames, folder names)
- Flag ambiguous matches needing review

**Phase 3: Staged Replacement** (contentManager_updateNote)
- Start with body text replacements
- Handle frontmatter separately
- Review filename changes last

**Phase 4: Verification**
- Confirm all replacements made
- Check for broken links from renamed files
- Validate frontmatter integrity

- Identify self-contained concepts per section
- Design link structure between resulting notes

- Create new atomic notes for each concept
- Add bidirectional links between related notes
- Update original note to MOC format

**Phase 4: Link Repair**
- Update external links pointing to original
- Add navigation links and backlinks
- Verify no orphaned content

Help me design and implement a consistent tagging system

There are several effective tagging architectures to consider:

**Option A: Flat Tags**
- Simple tags: #project, #meeting, #idea
- Easy to apply and remember
- Pros: Low friction
- Cons: Scales poorly, no hierarchy

**Option B: Hierarchical Tags**
- Nested tags: #project/work, #project/personal
- Built-in categorization
- Pros: Organized, filterable
- Cons: Longer to type, requires planning

**Option C: Faceted System**
- Multiple tag dimensions: type/, status/, topic/
- Each note gets tags from each facet
- Pros: Flexible queries, comprehensive
- Cons: More tags per note

**Option D: Minimal + Properties**
- Few tags for quick filtering
- Detailed metadata in frontmatter
- Pros: Clean tags, rich data
- Cons: Requires Dataview for querying

How many notes do you have, and what are your main ways of finding content?

**Option A: Central Attachments Folder**

- Cons: Loses context of which note uses what

**Option B: Note-Adjacent Storage**

- Pros: Context preserved, portable notes
- Cons: Scattered attachments

**Option C: Category-Based**
- Attachments/Screenshots/, Attachments/Diagrams/, etc.
- Organized by type rather than usage
- Pros: Find by type easily
- Cons: Requires consistent categorization

**Option D: Date-Based**
- Attachments/2024/01/, etc.
- Match Obsidian's default setting option
- Pros: Automatic organization
- Cons: Hard to find specific images

- All organization through links
- Pros: True to method, maximizes emergence
- Cons: Steep learning curve

**Option B: Hybrid Approach**

- Light folder structure (Inbox, Permanent, Literature)
- Heavy linking between notes
- Pros: Easier navigation, still link-centric
- Cons: Some structure overhead

**Option C: Modified for Digital**
- Use tags instead of ID prefixes
- MOCs replace physical index
- Folders by topic for easy browsing
- Pros: Familiar, leverages Obsidian features
- Cons: Less strict than original method

- Cons: External tool dependency

- Use Dataview for reference lists
- Pros: Queryable, no plugins
- Cons: Complex frontmatter

**Option D: Simple Link-Based**
- Web links to sources inline
- Minimal structure
- Pros: Fast, low overhead
- Cons: Limited organization

- Cons: Can become overwhelming

- Pros: Scalable, focused views
- Cons: More navigation steps

- Daily-focused dashboard

- Pros: Practical daily use
- Cons: Less comprehensive

**Option D: Graph-Based Navigation**
- Leverage Obsidian's graph view
- Color-code by type/area
- Entry point tags for filtering
- Pros: Visual discovery
- Cons: Less structured

Help me set up a reliable backup system for my vault

Vault backup strategies depend on your needs:

**Option A: Git Version Control**
- Initialize vault as git repository
- Commit changes regularly (manual or automated)
- Pros: Full history, branching, remote backup
- Cons: Learning curve, large binary handling

**Option B: Cloud Sync**
- Use iCloud, Dropbox, or OneDrive
- Automatic background sync
- Pros: Effortless, cross-device
- Cons: Sync conflicts possible, vendor lock-in

**Option C: Obsidian Sync**
- Native sync with version history
- End-to-end encryption option
- Pros: Optimized for Obsidian, reliable
- Cons: Paid service

**Option D: Manual Export + Archive**
- Periodic vault exports
- Store in multiple locations
- Pros: Full control, simple
- Cons: Manual effort, gaps between backups

What's most important to you - version history, automation, or simplicity?

Preparing notes for publication involves several considerations:

**Option A: Direct Export**
- Clean up formatting for target platform
- Remove internal links and private references
- Export as markdown or HTML
- Pros: Simple, preserves formatting
- Cons: Manual cleanup per post

**Option B: Publish-Ready Folder**
- Maintain separate publish versions
- Strip Obsidian-specific syntax
- Staging area before publication
- Pros: Review before publishing
- Cons: Duplicate maintenance

**Option C: Digital Garden Approach**
- Use Obsidian Publish or other tool
- Selective publishing with visibility tags
- Pros: Easy updates, public/private control
- Cons: Some content stays internal-only

**Option D: CMS Integration**
- Sync to headless CMS or blog platform
- Automated formatting conversion
- Pros: Professional workflow
- Cons: Technical setup required

What's your target platform, and do you want one-time exports or ongoing sync?

A journaling system can be structured several ways:

**Option A: Structured Daily Entries**
- Template with prompts (gratitude, goals, reflection)
- Consistent format for querying
- Pros: Easy to maintain, comparable entries
- Cons: Can feel rigid

**Option B: Freeform with Markers**
- Open writing with consistent tags/headings
- Use markers for moods, topics, highlights
- Pros: Natural expression, still searchable
- Cons: Requires discipline to mark up

**Option C: Multi-Type Journal**
- Different templates for different entry types
- Morning pages, evening reflection, gratitude, dreams
- Pros: Right format for right moment
- Cons: More templates to maintain

**Option D: Integrated with Daily Notes**
- Journal section within daily notes
- Tasks, logs, and reflection together
- Pros: Single daily touchpoint
- Cons: Less focused journaling space

**Phase 1: Staleness Detection** (vaultLibrarian_searchContent)

- Find notes with broken links or missing references
- Locate notes with incomplete content markers

**Phase 2: Triage**
- Categorize: update, archive, or delete
- Flag notes with dependencies
- Identify notes that others link to

**Phase 3: Safe Cleanup** (contentManager_updateNote / vaultManager_deleteFile)
- Update notes worth keeping
- Archive notes with historical value
- Delete only truly obsolete content

**Phase 4: Link Repair**
- Fix links pointing to deleted content
- Update references to archived content
- Verify no orphaned content remains

An OKR system in Obsidian can be implemented several ways:

**Option A: Hierarchical Notes**

- Cons: Manual progress tracking

**Option B: Frontmatter-Driven**
- Objectives with KRs in frontmatter properties
- Dataview tables for progress dashboards
- Pros: Queryable, visual progress
- Cons: Complex frontmatter management

**Option C: Project Integration**
- KRs linked to related project notes
- Progress auto-tracked from project status
- Pros: Work tied to goals
- Cons: Requires consistent project tracking

**Option D: Canvas-Based**
- Visual OKR map using Obsidian Canvas
- Drag to show relationships and progress
- Pros: Visual, intuitive
- Cons: Less structured data

- Cons: More organizational overhead

- Raw notes in course folders
- Processed notes extracted to permanent location
- Pros: Layered learning
- Cons: Requires regular processing

Create a system for tracking my health metrics and symptoms

Health tracking in Obsidian can balance privacy with functionality:

**Option A: Daily Log Integration**
- Health section in daily notes
- Track: sleep, exercise, mood, symptoms
- Dataview for trends over time
- Pros: Low friction, regular habit
- Cons: Limited visualization

**Option B: Dedicated Health Notes**
- Separate notes for each metric type
- Detailed tracking per category
- Pros: Deep tracking, focused review
- Cons: More notes to maintain

**Option C: Symptom Journal**
- Entry per symptom occurrence
- Rich context: triggers, duration, severity
- Pros: Doctor-ready records
- Cons: Only tracks issues, not wellness

**Option D: Periodic Check-ins**
- Weekly/monthly health review notes
- Summary metrics and reflection
- Pros: Less daily overhead
- Cons: Misses daily patterns

What aspects are most important to track - daily habits, specific symptoms, or periodic wellness reviews?

**Option B: Centralized Documentation Hub**

- Consistent template structure

- Links between related topics
- Pros: Knowledge connections
- Cons: Harder to navigate linearly

**Option D: Runbook Focus**
- Procedure-centric documentation
- Step-by-step guides for common tasks
- Pros: Immediately actionable
- Cons: Less conceptual depth

Create an idea capture and incubation system

An idea capture system needs to balance speed with organization:

**Option A: Quick Inbox + Processing**
- Fast capture to single inbox note
- Regular processing sessions to organize
- Pros: Zero-friction capture
- Cons: Requires discipline to process

**Option B: Categorized Quick Notes**
- Hotkeys for different idea types
- Templates pre-tag by category
- Pros: Some structure at capture
- Cons: Slightly more friction

**Option C: Fleeting Notes Flow**
- Zettelkasten-style capture
- Quick notes evolve into permanent notes
- Pros: Ideas develop naturally
- Cons: More processing overhead

**Option D: Voice + Auto-Transcribe**
- Voice memos linked to notes
- Transcribe and organize later
- Pros: Fastest capture
- Cons: Requires external tool

What's your typical idea capture context - at computer, mobile, or random moments?

Build a curated library of resources and references

A resource library can be organized several ways:

**Option A: Type-Based Organization**
- Folders: Articles, Books, Videos, Tools, Courses
- Each resource gets own note with summary
- Pros: Easy to browse by type
- Cons: Related resources scattered

**Option B: Topic-Based Organization**
- Folders by subject area
- Mixed resource types per topic
- Pros: Context-grouped learning
- Cons: Type-based filtering harder

**Option C: Tag-Based Flat Structure**
- All resources in one folder
- Rich tagging for type, topic, status
- Dataview queries create views
- Pros: Flexible, powerful search
- Cons: Requires consistent tagging

**Option D: Progressive Collection**
- Inbox  Processed  Evergreen
- Resources move as you engage with them
- Pros: Tracks engagement level
- Cons: More folder management

- Cons: Limited analysis across months

**Option B: Category-Based Tracking**
- Notes per spending category
- Monthly entries in each category
- Dataview for totals and trends
- Pros: Category insights
- Cons: More notes to maintain

**Option C: Transaction Log**
- Daily/weekly expense entries
- Frontmatter for amount, category, date
- Dataview queries for summaries
- Pros: Detailed tracking
- Cons: Many small notes

**Option D: Spreadsheet-Style Note**
- Large table in single note
- Filter with Advanced Tables plugin
- Pros: Familiar spreadsheet feel
- Cons: Less Obsidian-native

- Cons: Location info not reusable

- Build up location knowledge over time
- Pros: Reusable destination info
- Cons: More complex linking

- Packing list template

- Trip report template
- Pros: Consistent planning
- Cons: Templates may not fit all trips

**Option D: Minimal Journal Focus**
- Daily travel journal entries
- Photos and memories prioritized
- Pros: Captures experiences
- Cons: Less planning structure

**Option B: Calendar-Driven**

- Recurring task templates
- Pros: Time-based reminders
- Cons: System context lost

- Running log of all maintenance done
- Separate task list for upcoming
- Pros: Complete history
- Cons: Two places to check

**Option D: Appliance Inventory**
- Note per major appliance/system
  - Model, warranty, purchase date
  - Service history and contacts
- Pros: All info in one place
- Cons: More upfront setup

<workspace id="ws_1732830800000_stsbch78b" name="Private" />
</available_workspaces>
Track my accounts and login information

For account tracking, I strongly recommend NOT storing actual passwords in Obsidian. Instead, consider this approach:

**Recommended: Metadata Only**
- Track account existence and purpose
- Link to password manager entry
- Store non-sensitive info: username, email used, 2FA method
- Recovery info location (not the actual codes)

**Alternative Approaches:**

**Option A: Password Manager Integration**
- Use dedicated password manager
- Obsidian tracks context: what account is for, when created
- Pros: Secure credentials, rich context

**Option B: Encrypted Note Plugin**
- Use encryption plugin for sensitive notes
- Pros: All in one place
- Cons: Less secure than dedicated tools

**Option C: Reference-Only System**
- List accounts and their purposes
- Notes on security questions, backup codes location
- Pros: Useful without security risk

What's your current password management setup? I can help design a complementary system.

Build a searchable library of problems and solutions I've encountered

**Phase 1: Solution Template** (contentManager_createNote)
- Standardized format:
  - Problem description
  - Context/symptoms
  - Solution steps
  - Root cause (if known)
  - Related issues
  - Tags: domain, technology, error type

**Phase 2: Organization**
- Folder by domain or technology
- Rich tagging for cross-cutting search
- Link related solutions

**Phase 3: Quick Capture**
- Low-friction capture when solving problems
- Polish later for searchability
- Include error messages verbatim

**Phase 4: Search Optimization**
- Include common search terms
- Alias for different problem descriptions
- Link from project notes where encountered

This becomes a personal Stack Overflow. What domains do you solve problems in most often?

- Pros: Source attribution clear
- Cons: Topical search harder

**Option B: Theme-Organized**
- Quotes grouped by topic/theme
- Cross-source collections
- Pros: Find by subject
- Cons: Source context lost

**Option C: Chronological Capture**
- Quotes in order encountered
- Tags for themes and sources
- Pros: Reflects your journey
- Cons: Less organized browsing

**Option D: Spaced Review System**
- Quotes with review dates
- Random quote surfacing
- Pros: Active engagement
- Cons: More maintenance

**Option E: Linked to Notes**
- Quotes embedded where used
- Quote index with all excerpts
- Pros: Context of your thinking
- Cons: Scattered across vault

How do you want to use quotes - for writing, reflection, or sharing?

Home inventory serves both organization and insurance purposes:

**Option A: Category-Based Notes**
- Notes per category (electronics, furniture, etc.)
- Items listed with values and details
- Pros: Easy browsing by type
- Cons: Finding specific items harder

**Option B: Room-Based Organization**
- Notes per room/area
- Photos of items in context
- Pros: Physical location mapped
- Cons: Items span rooms

**Option C: Individual Item Notes**
- Note per valuable item
- Serial numbers, receipts, photos
- Frontmatter for searchable metadata
- Pros: Comprehensive per item
- Cons: Many notes to manage

**Option D: Master Spreadsheet-Style**
- Single note with comprehensive table
- All items in one view
- Pros: Quick reference
- Cons: Limited detail per item

Is this primarily for insurance purposes, organization, or both?

- Note variations and effectiveness
- Pros: Detailed optimization data
- Cons: More logging effort

**Option C: Weekly Review Focus**
- Weekly reflection on routine adherence
- Note what worked, what didn't
- Adjust routine periodically
- Pros: Less daily overhead
- Cons: Less immediate feedback

**Option D: Routine Definition Note**
- Document ideal routine
- Version as you iterate
- Link to habit tracker for execution
- Pros: Clear reference
- Cons: Execution separate

**Option A: Role-Based Organization**
- Sections per role/function
- Onboarding paths per position
- Pros: Easy for new team members
- Cons: Cross-functional info duplicated

**Option B: Process-Centric**
- Organized by business process
- End-to-end documentation
- Pros: Complete workflows
- Cons: Finding specific info harder

**Option C: Wiki-Style**
- Topic-based with rich linking
- Central index with many paths
- Pros: Flexible navigation
- Cons: Can become chaotic

**Option D: FAQ + Reference**
- Common questions answered
- Reference docs for deep dives
- Pros: Quick answers + depth
- Cons: May miss context

What's the main goal - onboarding new members, reducing repeated questions, or preserving institutional knowledge?

Help me clean up and reorganize my entire vault

A full vault reorganization requires a systematic approach:

**Phase 1: Assessment** (vaultLibrarian_searchContent)
- Count notes by folder and age
- Identify orphaned notes (no links)
- Find duplicates and near-duplicates
- Map current tag usage

**Phase 2: Structure Design**
- Design new folder structure
- Plan tagging taxonomy
- Define naming conventions
- Create templates for note types

**Phase 3: Migration** (vaultManager_moveItem)
- Process folder by folder
- Reorganize into new structure
- Update links as needed
- Add missing metadata

**Phase 4: Cleanup**
- Remove duplicates and obsolete content
- Fix broken links
- Archive rarely-used content
- Document the new system

This is significant work - I recommend doing it in stages. Which areas of your vault need the most attention?

Create a system for saving important emails to my vault

Email archiving in Obsidian can follow several approaches:

**Option A: Thread-Based Notes**
- One note per email thread
- Copy important content, link context
- Pros: Preserves conversation
- Cons: Manual copying work

**Option B: Reference-Only Links**
- Note with links back to email
- Brief summary and context
- Pros: No duplication
- Cons: Email access required

**Option C: Topic Extraction**
- Extract decisions/actions to relevant notes
- Link to email for context
- Pros: Info where it's useful
- Cons: Email thread split up

**Option D: Inbox Processing**
- Capture actionable items
- Archive reference info
- Pros: GTD-style processing
- Cons: Requires discipline

What's the main goal - preserving reference info, tracking action items, or both?

- Captures full article or selection
- Pros: Native integration
- Cons: Limited formatting control

**Option B: Read-Later Service Integration**
- Pocket, Instapaper, Readwise
- Sync to Obsidian periodically
- Pros: Better reading experience
- Cons: Extra service

**Option C: Manual Curation**
- Copy key excerpts with source link
- Add your own commentary
- Pros: Higher quality captures
- Cons: More effort

**Option D: Reference-Only Bookmarks**
- Just save URLs with brief notes
- Read on original site
- Pros: Minimal overhead
- Cons: Content may disappear

- Quick improvements over time
- Pros: Surfaces forgotten content
- Cons: No prioritization

**Option B: Age-Based Queue**
- Review notes by last-modified date
- Dataview query for stale notes
- Pros: Systematic coverage
- Cons: May review low-value notes

**Option C: Importance-Weighted**
- Tag notes by review priority
- Focus on high-value content
- Pros: Efficient use of time
- Cons: Lower notes never reviewed

**Option D: Spaced Repetition**
- Apply SRS to note review
- Notes appear based on interval
- Pros: Efficient learning
- Cons: More tracking overhead

Document my Obsidian plugins and their configurations

Plugin documentation helps with setup reproduction and troubleshooting:

**Option A: Single Config Note**
- All plugins listed with settings
- Quick reference for setup
- Pros: One place to check
- Cons: Can get long

**Option B: Per-Plugin Notes**
- Note for each significant plugin
- Configuration, use cases, tips
- Pros: Detailed per plugin
- Cons: More notes

**Option C: Category-Based**
- Group by function (editing, navigation, search, etc.)
- Compare alternatives tried
- Pros: Functional organization
- Cons: Plugin may fit multiple

**Option D: Essential Only**
